questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text:
Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021)

  1. Pyloric stricture
  2. Asymptomatic phase
  3. Gastrointestinal bleeding
  4. Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several stages, each with distinct symptoms that appear in a specific order. The stages are:

 

 

Treatment of Iron toxicity – Deferoxamine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to reverse muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the anticholinesterase of choice for reversing neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium. When neuromuscular blockade needs to be reversed at the end of surgery, approximately 80% of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction are already free of vecuronium molecules. The remaining blockade can be reversed by increasing the acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine. By preventing acetylcholine breakdown, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which competes with the remaining vecuronium molecules and overcomes the residual blockade.

 

It's important to note that while sugammadex is the drug of choice for immediate and complete reversal of vecuronium (when full dose has been given and immediate reversal is needed), neostigmine remains the standard choice for routine reversal at the end of surgery. Neostigmine is typically administered with atropine or glycopyrrolate to counteract its muscarinic side effects such as bradycardia and bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: This is an anticholinergic drug that is used alongside neostigmine, not for reversing neuromuscular blockade itself, but to counter the extra-neuromuscular junction effects of neostigmine. Atropine prevents the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine such as bradycardia, increased salivation, and bronchospasm. It has no direct effect on reversing vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: While physostigmine is also an anticholinesterase like neostigmine, it is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade. Physostigmine crosses the blood-brain barrier (unlike neostigmine) and is primarily used for treating central anticholinergic syndrome and certain types of poisoning. It is not the drug of choice for reversing peripheral neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: This is completely incorrect as succinylcholine is itself a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, not a reversal agent. It would actually cause muscle relaxation rather than reverse it. Succinylcholine is used for rapid sequence intubation and short procedures requiring muscle relaxation, and would worsen rather than reverse the effects of vecuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the anticholinesterase drug of choice for reversing non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade (such as that caused by vecuronium) by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase and increasing acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve passes through the structure indicated by the arrow in the given image? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text: Isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for congestive heart failure in combination with which of the following vasodilators? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydralazine

 

Combining hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate (ISDN) is recommended for CHF.

 

The mechanism of action of hydralazine, a direct vasodilator, remains unknown. Moreover, it lowers nitrate tolerance. The combination of ISDN and hydralazine has been shown to have reduced mortality in patients of CHF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minoxidil: Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator used primarily for severe hypertension and not typically combined with ISDN for CHF.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat subarachnoid hemorrhage and is not indicated for CHF.

 

Option D. Nitrendipine: Nitrendipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension but is not commonly used in combination with ISDN for CHF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for the treatment of congestive heart failure, as it effectively reduces both preload and afterload, improving cardiac function and reducing symptoms and mortality in CHF patients.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

 

Explanation

 

Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.

 

Mechanism of enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex: Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.

 

Option B. Enterocolic Reflex: Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.

 

Option C. Gastroileal Reflex: Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.

 

Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Duodenal distension
  2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  3. Acidity of the chyme
  4. Osmolality of the chyme
  5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perenei

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani. The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition that separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below. It consists of two paired muscles, the levator ani and the coccygeus (also known as the ischiococcygeus or the pubococcygeus), and their fascial coverings.

 

The levator ani muscle is a broad, thin muscle that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It consists of three parts: the pubococcygeus, the iliococcygeus, and the puborectalis.

 

  • Pubococcygeus muscle is the most medial of the three, and it arises from the pubic bone and the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle.
  • Iliococcygeus muscle arises from the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial spine.
  • Puborectalis muscle is a sling-like muscle that forms a loop around the anorectal junction, and it arises from the pubic bone.

 

The coccygeus muscle is a small, triangular muscle that lies posterior to the levator ani muscle. It arises from the ischial spine and the sacrospinous ligament and inserts onto the coccyx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles, which are part of the levator ani muscle group. These muscles, including the puborectalis and coccygeus, contribute to the floor of the pelvic cavity and provide structural support, separating the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

 

A-3. Rotavirus is a member of the Reoviridae family, which is an exception among RNA viruses because it has double-stranded RNA (dsRNA).

 

B-1. SARS-CoV-2 is a coronavirus, which is a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

 

C-4. Parvovirus is a unique DNA virus because it has single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).

 

D-2. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) belongs to the Papillomaviridae family and has double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the nucleic acid composition of viruses is crucial. Rotavirus has dsRNA, SARS-CoV-2 has ssRNA, Parvovirus has ssDNA, and HPV has dsDNA.

questions.text: All of the following are boundaries of the quadrangular space, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Supraspinatus

 

Explanation:

 

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical landmark in the scapular region where the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels pass. The correct boundaries of this space include teres minor superiorly (forming the superior boundary), teres major inferiorly (forming the inferior boundary), long head of triceps medially (forming the medial boundary), and the surgical neck of humerus laterally. Supraspinatus is not a boundary of this space - it lies in the supraspinous fossa of the scapula, superior to the region of the quadrangular space.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Teres minor: This is actually a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its superior border. It is one of the rotator cuff muscles originating from the lateral border of the scapula.
  • Option C. Teres major: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its inferior border. It originates from the dorsal surface of the inferior angle of the scapula.
  • Option D. Long head of triceps: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its medial border. It originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadrangular space is bounded by teres minor superiorly, teres major inferiorly, long head of triceps medially, and the surgical neck of humerus laterally - with the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels as its contents.

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: What is the action at the hip joint of the muscle that attaches to the region marked in the image below? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

choices.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

  • Hyponatremia is more commonly observed in individuals taking oxcarbazepine compared to those taking carbamazepine.
  • Both of these antiepileptic drugs can contribute to hyponatremia by enhancing the effects of ADH (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased retention of water, which in turn reduces the osmolarity and causes hyponatremia. However, the incidence of hyponatremia appears to be higher with oxcarbazepine when compared to carbamazepine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Hypotension is more commonly seen with carbamazepine. It can affect cardiovascular function and lead to decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Rash: Rash is a common side effect of both drugs, but it is more frequently seen with carbamazepine. Skin reactions can range from mild to severe, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

 

Option D. Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidases (GGT): Elevated GGT levels are more commonly associated with carbamazepine use. GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, and its elevated levels can indicate liver enzyme induction or liver injury, which is more common with carbamazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: How would you describe the tonicity of the fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotonic

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is isotonic.

 

Normally, about 65 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. The PCT is the site of maximum water reabsorption under normal physiological conditions. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT, so the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and proportional to each other. Water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through aquaporin-1 which are active water channels. Reabsorption of sodium and water in PCT is not affected by ADH levels.

 

Thus, even in the absence of ADH, fluid is isotonic in PCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotonic: This is incorrect because the fluid in the PCT remains isotonic due to the proportional reabsorption of solutes and water.

 

Option C. Hypertonic: This is incorrect because the reabsorption process in the PCT maintains the isotonic nature of the fluid.

 

Option D. Depends on fluid intake: This is incorrect because the tonicity of the fluid in the PCT does not depend on fluid intake but on the intrinsic reabsorption processes that maintain isotonic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is isotonic due to the isosmotic reabsorption of solutes and water, regardless of the presence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). This ensures that the fluid entering the loop of Henle has the same osmolarity as plasma.

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

 

Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the options given above except the pituitary gland. The pituitary does not play a direct role in iodide transport or thyroid hormone synthesis, hence the absence of NIS.

 

The sodium/iodide cotransporter, also known as the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS) is a transmembrane glycoprotein, which transports two sodium cations (Na+) for each iodide anion (I−) into the cell. NIS mediated uptake of iodide into follicular cells of the thyroid gland is the first step in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: The primary site of NIS expression, essential for thyroid hormone production.

 

Option B. Placenta: NIS is expressed to transport iodide to the fetus, crucial for fetal development.

 

Option D. Salivary gland: NIS facilitates iodide transport, although its precise role here is less clear.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is essential for iodide transport in various tissues. The NIS seen in:

 

  • Thyroid
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands
  • Certain cancers are derived from these tissues.

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

questions.text: The Para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

Epiploic foramen is the structure indicated in the provided image. The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

 

 

The caudate lobe is a small lobe of the liver situated on the posterior aspect, between the sulcus for the vena cava on the right and the fissure for the ligamentum venosum on the left. The caudate lobe forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is the first part of the small intestine immediately beyond the stomach. While the duodenum is closely related to the epiploic foramen, specifically the posterior surface of its first part, it does not form the superior border. Instead, it comprises the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the start of the duodenum. The free edge of the lesser omentum contains the bile duct, hepatic artery, and portal vein, forming the anterior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower and middle body into the right atrium of the heart. It is located posteriorly to the epiploic foramen but does not form the superior border. It creates the posterior boundary, similar to the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a key anatomical passage within the abdominal cavity that connects the greater sac to the lesser sac.

 

The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of this foramen.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug
Misbranded drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A misbranded drug refers to a drug whose labeling is inaccurate or misleading. This includes incorrect labeling of the quantity of active ingredients. In this scenario, where the medication is labeled as containing 500 mg of paracetamol but actually contains only 200 mg, it would be considered a misbranded drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: These products are manufactured concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product. The product may or may not contain the active ingredients. Spurious drugs are usually manufactured by unlicensed anti-social elements but sometimes licensed manufacturers may also be involved.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: These are those drugs which are found to contain an adulterant/substituted product or contaminated with filth rendering it injurious to health

 

Option C. Unethical drug: "Unethical drug" is not a standard term in pharmaceutical regulation. The issue here is not primarily about ethics but rather about the accuracy of labeling and drug quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug labeled inaccurately with respect to its active ingredient quantity is considered a misbranded drug. Ensuring accurate labeling is crucial for regulatory compliance and consumer safety, as it ensures that drugs on the market are labeled truthfully and can be trusted for their intended use.

questions.text: Baroreceptors are associated with which vessel? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:


Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the walls of blood vessels that monitor blood pressure. The carotid sinus is a small dilation of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid into external and internal carotid branches. These baroreceptors are specifically located in the adventitial layer of the vessel wall within this dilation. They sense changes in arterial pressure and transmit this information via the carotid sinus nerve (branch of glossopharyngeal nerve) to the medulla.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. External carotid artery: Baroreceptors are not located in the external carotid artery. They are specifically found in the carotid sinus, which is a dilation at the beginning of the internal carotid artery.
  • Option c. Subclavian artery: No baroreceptors are documented in the subclavian artery. The main locations of baroreceptors are the carotid sinus and the aortic arch.
  • Option d. Brachiocephalic trunk: While this vessel branches off the aortic arch, it is not specifically identified as containing baroreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are primarily located in two key areas: the carotid sinus (a dilation of the internal carotid artery) and the aortic arch. These pressure sensors are crucial for the short-term regulation of blood pressure via the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PGE1

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) keeps the ductus arteriosus open (PDA). It is useful in maintaining the patency of the Ductus Arteriosus in term neonates who are awaiting surgical correction of underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease and having a duct dependent circulation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. PGF2α: PGF2α (prostaglandin F2α) is involved in various physiological functions, including uterine contractions, but does not play a role in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. PGH2: PGH2 (prostaglandin H2) is a precursor in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway but does not directly maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. PGI2: PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation but is not specifically used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Educational Objective

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) is used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects that require an open ductus arteriosus for adequate oxygenation and circulation.

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a patient with a recurrent chalazion involving the upper eyelid. What is the most likely diagnosis on histopathology? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous Cell Carcinoma

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma can often masquerade as a recurrent chalazion, making it a diagnostic challenge. It arises from the meibomian glands and frequently involves the upper eyelid. This malignancy typically presents initially as a nodule that may be mistaken for a chalazion, more frequently on the upper eyelid. Recurrent chalazion that doesn't respond to conventional treatment should raise suspicion for this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: While this is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelids (90% of eyelid malignancies), it typically presents as a noduloulcerative lesion with pearly rolled margins (rodent ulcer). It most commonly affects the lower eyelid (50%) followed by medial canthus, and doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: This presents as a scaly, erythematous plaque with elevated and indurated margins or occasionally as nodular/polypoidal growth. It commonly arises from the lid margin, not from the meibomian glands, and doesn't typically resemble a chalazion.

 

Option D. Malignant Melanoma: This rare eyelid tumor (less than 1% of eyelid lesions) presents as a pigmented, well-defined lesion that later becomes elevated, or as a nodular growth. It doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recurrent chalazia, especially in older patients, should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, warranting histopathological examination to avoid misdiagnosis of this potentially lethal malignancy.

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: Which of the following systems exhibits a feedback gain of infinity in negative feedback mechanism? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood volume control by kidney

 

The regulation of blood volume by the kidney, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism. When blood volume decreases, the kidney responds by conserving water and producing concentrated urine to help increase blood volume. Conversely, when blood volume increases, the kidney excretes excess water to reduce blood volume. This process is regulated by hormones like aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and helps maintain the body's fluid balance within a relatively narrow range until the error becomes zero leading to infinite gain.

 

The feedback gain is designed to be adaptive and responsive, preventing extreme deviations but not amplifying them to infinity. The other options (B. Temperature control in hypothalamus and C. BP control by baroreceptors) also involve negative feedback mechanisms that aim to maintain stability, not infinite gain.

 

Negative feedback is a regulatory mechanism in which a system responds to a stimulus by producing an output that opposes the stimulus, thereby reducing the deviation from the desired set point. In such a system, the feedback gain refers to the strength of the feedback loop, or the degree to which the output is affected by changes in the input.   

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature control in hypothalamus: This system also uses negative feedback but does not achieve infinite gain. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by initiating responses that either dissipate heat (e.g., sweating) or conserve heat (e.g., shivering).

 

Option C. BP control by baroreceptors: Baroreceptors provide negative feedback for blood pressure control by adjusting heart rate and vessel diameter. While effective, this system does not have infinite gain.

 

Option D. incorrect Infinite gain is seen in the regulation of blood volume by the kidney, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism. it helps maintain the body's fluid balance within a relatively narrow range until the error becomes zero leading to infinite gain. be used to describe highly effective regulatory systems of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood volume control by the kidney exemplifies a highly effective negative feedback mechanism, theoretically approaching infinite gain by maintaining blood volume within a narrow range. While true infinite gain is not possible in biological systems, the kidneys' regulatory function is exceptionally efficient.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario presented here is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is caused by a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, denoted as 3.

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together using the mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

 

Other features that may be associated with DiGeorge syndrome include developmental delays, learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders. Treatment usually involves managing the individual symptoms and providing support to address any developmental or behavioral challenges

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1 - first pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, primarily associated with the development of structures like the middle ear and Eustachian tube.

 

Option B (2 - second pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, related to formations such as the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D (4 - fourth pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, although related to the development of superior parathyroid glands, it is not primarily responsible for the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands like the third pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

 

 

The third pharyngeal pouch's proper development is crucial for the normal formation of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Disruption in this development can lead to significant clinical symptoms like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, emphasizing the need for genetic testing and comprehensive clinical management in affected individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate concerning a chalazion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with Severe Pain

 

A chalazion is characterized by being painless rather than painful. Chalazion symptoms include "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size." It is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland" that develops without significant pain, which contrasts with painful conditions like hordeolum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Onset: Correct statement. Chalazion is defined as a "chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation" that develops gradually with "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size."

 

Option B. Involvement of the Meibomian Gland: Correct statement. Chalazion is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland."

 

Option D. Characterized by Granulomatous Inflammation: Correct statement. A chalazion is definitively a "lipogranulomatous inflammation."

 

Contrast with painful lid conditions: Unlike chalazion, conditions like hordeolum externum (stye) and hordeolum internum are characterized by "acute pain associated with swelling of the lid." In hordeolum internum, the pain is even described as "more intense, due to the swelling being embedded deeply in the dense fibrous tissue."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chalazion is a painless, chronic, lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland, which distinguishes it from painful acute lid conditions like hordeolum.

questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Levopropoxyphene

 

  • Propoxyphene has two isomers: Levopropoxyphene and Dextropropoxyphene. Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive. It is an opioid derivative that acts centrally as a strong and partial µ receptor agonist and helps to reduce the cough reflex. It has no analgesic property but can cause some degree of sedation. Please note that the other isomer dextropropoxyphene is mainly used as an analgesic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ambroxol is derived from bromhexine. It increases mucociliary clearance, thereby providing relief in productive cough. Thus it is primarily used as a mucolytic (not anti-tussive). Further it is not an opioid.

 

Option B. Diphenoxylate or Loperamide is indicated for non-infective diarrhea. These are not used as anti-tussive.

 

Option D. Levorphanol is a synthetic opioid which is chiefly used in the management of moderate to severe pain. It also have some anti-tussive properties similar to codeine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid specifically used for its antitussive properties. While levorphanol is also an opioid with antitussive effects, it is more commonly used for pain relief. Levopropoxyphene's primary indication as an antitussive makes it the most appropriate choice among the given options.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

choices.text: Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children

questions.text: Which statement about Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) in children is accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children 

 

Explanation:

 

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children, after Minimal Change Disease (MCD). FSGS accounts for approximately 10-15% of pediatric nephrotic syndrome cases. It is characterized by sclerosis in parts (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli, with fusion of the foot processes of podocytes visible on electron microscopy.

 

FSGS is often associated with the NPHS2 gene mutation, which affects the protein podocin in the glomerular filtration barrier. This mutation is frequently linked to steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, making FSGS a significant cause of both primary and secondary steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in the pediatric population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Good response to steroids - INCORRECT. FSGS is typically characterized by poor response to steroids. Most cases are steroid-resistant, which is one of the indicators for performing a renal biopsy in children with nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Relapses are rare - INCORRECT. In FSGS, relapses are common, and the disease often follows a progressive course leading to end-stage renal disease in many patients if not effectively treated.

 

Option D. Renal biopsy is not required - INCORRECT. Renal biopsy is essential for diagnosing FSGS. It is indicated in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome and is the only definitive way to diagnose FSGS and distinguish it from other causes of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

FSGS is the second most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (after Minimal Change Disease), is typically steroid-resistant, requires renal biopsy for diagnosis, and has a higher risk of progression to end-stage renal disease compared to MCD.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
